content.title: Venous Malformations
content.definition: Low-flow vascular malformations composed of ectatic venous channels with defective smooth muscle development. Present at birth (though may not be clinically apparent), grow proportionally with the patient, and never spontaneously involute. Most common vascular malformation seen in clinical practice.

blue_rubber_bleb_nevus.features: Multiple cutaneous and GI venous malformations

pathophysiology.defect: Abnormal smooth muscle development in venous wall

coagulopathy.significance: Predicts extent of disease, risk of thrombus

clinical_presentation.location: Any body region, commonly head/neck, extremities

symptoms.functional: Depending on location - difficulty swallowing, visual compromise

natural_history: May expand with hormonal changes, trauma

ultrasound_doppler.findings: Compressible hypoechoic mass, low or absent flow

laboratory.fibrinogen: May be low in extensive lesions

learning_objectives: Differentiate venous malformations from infantile hemangiomas
Recognize clinical and imaging features of venous malformations
clinical_pearls: VMs are PRESENT AT BIRTH (unlike hemangiomas which appear at 1-2 weeks)
VMs NEVER involute (unlike hemangiomas which involute by age 5-7)
MRI T2 'light bulb sign' is characteristic - bright on T2
Elevated D-dimer suggests extensive disease with localized intravascular coagulopathy
Sclerotherapy is first-line treatment for most venous malformations
common_misconceptions: Misconception: 'Hemangioma' is synonym for vascular malformation - Reality: Hemangiomas are tumors that proliferate and involute; VMs are malformations present at birth

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
